summary: This is an email chain between Assistant United States Attorneys discussing a request from Judge Engelmayer regarding a FOIA case (Times v. BOP). The judge asks the U.S. Attorney to reconsider the government's position on withholding BOP documents related to Jeffrey Epstein, given the change in administration, as the documents are being withheld due to potential interference with two ongoing criminal cases.

persons.name: Judge Engelmayer
persons.context: Presiding judge in the FOIA case Times v. BOP. He expressed skepticism about the breadth of documents withheld and requested the U.S. Attorney to reconsider the government's position in light of the new administration.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The FOIA case seeks Bureau of Prisons (BOP) records related to him. His death and the circumstances surrounding it are central to the related criminal cases cited as reasons for withholding documents.

persons.name: Noel
persons.context: One of two BOP employees prosecuted in U.S. v. Noel (19-cr-930), a case related to their duty the night of Epstein's death. This prosecution is cited as a reason for withholding documents under FOIA Exemption 7(A).

persons.name: Tartaglione
persons.context: A former police officer and death penalty defendant in U.S. v. Tartaglione (16-cr-832), who was briefly Epstein's cellmate. This prosecution is also cited as a reason for withholding documents under FOIA Exemption 7(A).

connections.description: Tartaglione was briefly Epstein's cellmate at the time of Epstein's apparent suicide attempt, as mentioned in the context of the FOIA withholding justification.
Judge Engelmayer is presiding over a FOIA case where the New York Times is seeking BOP documents related to Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Oral Argument in Times v. BOP
events.description: Judge Engelmayer held an oral argument regarding the FOIA case where he expressed skepticism about the breadth of BOP documents withheld related to Jeffrey Epstein and made a request to the U.S. Attorney.

events.title: Change of U.S. Administration
events.description: Referenced by Judge Engelmayer as a reason for the U.S. Attorney to potentially reconsider the government's position on withholding BOP documents related to Epstein.

keyFacts: The New York Times is seeking Bureau of Prisons (BOP) records related to Jeffrey Epstein through a FOIA lawsuit (Times v. BOP).

BOP is withholding a substantial number of documents under FOIA Exemption 7(A), citing potential interference with two ongoing SDNY criminal cases: U.S. v. Noel (prosecution of two BOP employees on duty the night Epstein died) and U.S. v. Tartaglione (a death penalty case where the defendant was briefly Epstein's cellmate).

Judge Engelmayer requested the U.S. Attorney to 'take a close look at the case' and consider whether to confer with officials at Main Justice (DOJ headquarters) about potentially reevaluating BOP's FOIA response in light of the change in administration in January 2020.
